Data request through the UCC-SMART Study group (available via Data request UCC-SMART).
For release of biological samples stored in the biobank, approval from the UMCU biobank has to be obtained.
Data Access Description: Email request to PI (Mirjam Geerlings).

Name: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Express Biobank Study
Description: Objectives: (1) Follow-up study: To study the predictive value of locally expressed proteins for the occurrence of adverse cardiovascular events in patients undergoing open-surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA); (2) Cross-sectional studies: To study and validate differential gene and protein expression in AAA material (blood or tissue) among patient groups and histological phenotypes; (3)  Integrative studies: To combine genomic (whole genome SNP and CNV analyses), proteomic and medical data to identify subgroups of patients at risk for adverse cardiovascular events. The current (March 2017) number of included AAA patients is over 700 patients, most of whom underwent AAA open-surgery. All patients are followed for a minimum of three years.
Sample Access Description: We are always looking out to broaden our collaborative efforts with respect to our genomic data, so feel free to contact us: sander.vanderlaan@atheroexpress.nl
Data Access Description: We are always looking out to broaden our collaborative efforts with respect to our genomic data, so feel free to contact us: sander.vanderlaan@atheroexpress.nl

Name: Centrale Biobank Universitair Medisch Centrum Utrecht
Description: Biopsies and tissue in frozen material and paraffin.

Name: COVID-19 impact on child development: add-on study of the YOUth longitudinal child cohort
Description: The following questionnaires are filled out by approximately 1500 children and (one of their) parents who participate in the YOUth cohort study: 1) Brief Symptom Inventory (BSI, pregnant women or primary caretaker): depression; anxiety; self-reported symptoms of psychopathology; physical symptoms; 2) NIMH CRISIS questionnaire (Dutch translation, primary caretake self-report and parent-report about child): (family) exposure to COVID-19, stress levels; emotions; lifestyle; social contacts/relationships; physical exercise; social media use; substance abuse (parents only); children's education. Both questionnaires were sent out during/day care school closures, after school/day care reopening, and will be sent out again at the end of September and the end of the pandemic (as declared by the WHO). Data are available for use for non-commercial academic research.

Name: CAPACITY
Description: CAPACITY is a registry of patients with COVID-19 across Europe and has been established to answer questions on the role of cardiovascular disease in this pandemic. It is an extension of the Case Record Form (CRF) that was released by the ISARIC (International Severe Acute Respiratory and Emerging Infection Consortium) and WHO (World Health Organisation) in response to the emerging outbreak of COVID-19. The aim of CAPACITY is to collect data regarding the cardiovascular history, diagnostic information and occurrence of cardiovascular complications in COVID-19 patients. By collecting this information in a standardized manner, CAPACITY can aid in providing more insight in (1) the incidence of cardiovascular complications in patients with COVID-19, and (2) the vulnerability and clinical course of COVID-19 in patients with an underlying cardiovascular disease. The CAPACITY study is an initiative of the DCVA (Dutch CardioVascular Alliance) involving numerous biobanks and hospitals across the Netherlands. For more information see https://capacity-covid.eu or contact Info@capacity-covid.eu
Data Access Description: yes, please visit website

Name: CAIRO 2
Description: Cetuximab Added to Capecitabine, Oxaliplatin and Bevacizumab in Patients With Previously Untreated Advanced Colorectal Carcinoma: a Randomised Phase III Study. Primary objective:To assess the efficacy, defined as progression-free survival (PFS), of adding cetuximab to capecitabine/oxaliplatin/bevacizumab for advanced  colorectal cancer (CRC).   Inclusion criteria: Patients with histological proof of colon or rectal carcinoma, advanced disease not amenable for curative surgery, measurable disease parameters and no previous systemic chemotherapy for advanced disease. Adjuvant chemotherapy was allowed provided that the last administration was at least 6 months before randomisation. Data collection:  CT scans, CMS data, MMR status questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, HE slides, circulating tumour cells (CTC) , circulating endothelial cells (CECs), DNA, serum. Experimental data: Genomics, proteomics, pharmacogenomics. Molecular analyses: SNP analyses, MALDI-TOF protein profiling,  Tissue microarray (TMA): expression of  Epidermal Growth Factor receptor, Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor, Microvessel Density and Mismatch Repair Genes.

Name: Youth of Utrecht
Description:
The YOUth cohort is funded through a NWO Gravitation grant to the Consortium Individual Development. YOUth is a longitudinal cohort study with repeated measurements that focuses on neurocognitive development (i.e. brain and cognitive development) involved in two core characteristics of behavioural development: social competence and behavioural control. The YOUth cohort includes participants either during pregnancy, or around 9 years of age. The first group, YOUth Baby & Child, aims to include 3000 pregnant women at 20 weeks of pregnancy, and their partners through hospitals and midwifery practices. The second group, YOUth Child & Teenager, aims to include 3000 children aged 8, 9 or 10 and their parents through primary schools. So, in total 6000 children and their mothers and fathers will be repeatedly tested using a test battery including EEG/ERP (in infants and young children), structural and functional MRI (in school-age children), and eye-tracking, behavioural, and computer tasks, suited to study the effect of biological, child-related and environmental characteristics on the developing brain, and subsequently on the developing behaviour.

YOUth applies a flexible longitudinal design for the cohorts. This means that children will be measured at broader age ranges (3-year age ranges) at each wave. The main benefit of the flexible age design is that it will provide more detailed information on the neurodevelopmental curves over time.

3000 pregnant women, 3000 partners, 3000 babies
3000 Children 8,9,10 years old, 6000 parents
Sample Access Description:
When a researcher (level of postdoc or higher) wishes to access YOUth data for scientific analyses he/she will have to submit a short proposal to the publication committee in the format that will be available on the YOUth website (https://www.uu.nl/en/research/youth-cohort-study/about-the-youth-cohort-study/youth-data-collection). This request should always be in collaboration with one of the members of the publication committee. In the case of a students or PhD project, the proposal should be submitted by the PhDs supervisor. 
Collaboration in consortia cannot be granted to an individual researcher, but only be initiated through and with the approval of the Executive Board on behalf of the YOUth cohort. 
In case of the use of biological samples, additional approval of the UMCU Biobank research ethics committee. After approval by the YOUth Data access committee, the applicant needs to apply for approval to this committee. 
After the proposal is approved the researcher will have access to the data
Data Access Description:
When a researcher (level of postdoc or higher) wishes to access YOUth data for scientific analyses he/she will have to submit a short proposal to the publication committee in the format that will be available on the YOUth website (https://www.uu.nl/en/research/youth-cohort-study/about-the-youth-cohort-study/youth-data-collection). This request should always be in collaboration with one of the members of the publication committee. Collaboration in consortia cannot be granted to an individual researcher, but only be initiated through and with the approval of the Executive Board on behalf of the YOUth cohort.

Name: CAIRO 4
Description:
The role of surgery of the primary tumour with few or absent symptoms in patients with synchronous unresectable metastases of colorectal cancer: a multicenter randomized phase III study. Study design: Patients with synchronous metastatic colorectal cancer with few or absent symptoms of their primary tumour are randomized 1:1 between systemic
treatment without resection of the primary tumour and resection of the primary tumour followed by systemic treatment. 
Primary objective: To determine the clinical benefit in terms of overall survival of resection of the primary tumour in synchronous unresectable metastatic colorectal cancer. Inclusion criteria: Resectable primary tumour in situ, unresectable distant metastases, no indication for neo-adjuvant (chemo)radiation. Data collection: Questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, plasma, serum.

Name: Colopec II
Description: Second and third look laparoscopy in pT4 colon cancer patients for early detection of peritoneal metastases: a randomized multicentre trial. Primary objective: To determine the added value of a third look diagnostic laparoscopy (DLS) after a negative second look DLS in pT4N0-2M0 colon cancer patients to detect peritoneal metastases (PM) at a subclinical stage. Inclusion criteria: Curative intent resection (R0/R1) of pT4a,bN0-2M0 colon cancer, proximal rectal  cancer, or small bowel cancer, with or without adjuvant systemic therapy. Data collection: CT scans, questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, plasma, ctDNA. Experimental data: Genomics

Name: FORCE trial
Description: Pelvic Floor Rehabilitation to improve functional Outcome and quality of life after surgery for Rectal Cancer: a randomized controlled trial. Primary objective: To evaluate the effect of Pelvic Floor Rehabilitation compared to standard treatment on fecal incontinence in patients after low anterior resection, by measuring the Wexner-score. Inclusion criteria: Patients who underwent low anterior resection for rectal carcinoma. Data collection: Questionnaires

Name: MOCCAS
Description: Molecular stool testing for Colorectal CAncer Surveillance (MOCCAS) study. Primary objective: To determine the performance characteristics of two established non-invasive tests, the multitarget stool DNA test Cologuard® and the faecal immunochemical test (FIT) in the detection of colorectal cancer (CRC) as an alternative for colonoscopy surveillance. Inclusion criteria: Subjects in the age group 50-75 years, with history of polypectomy or CRC, as well as subjects under surveillance for familial colorectal cancer (FCC). Data collection: Questionnaires. Sample collection: Feaces. Experimental data: Genomics, methylation, quantification of haemoglobin.

Name: BIOPEX-2
Description: Perineal wound closure using gluteal turnover flap or primary closure after abdominoperineal resection for rectal cancer: a randomised controlled multicenter trial. Study design: This is a multicentre study in which patients undergoing an abdominoperineal resection (APR) are randomised between standard care using primary closure of the perineum and the experimental arm with assisted closure using a gluteal turnover (GT) flap. Primary objective: To determine the additional value of a minimally invasive gluteal turnover flap for perineal wound healing after APR for rectal cancer in comparison to primary closure. Inclusion criteria: Resection of primary or recurrent rectal carcinoma by abdominoperineal resection. Data collection: CT scans, questionnaires.

Name: IMARI
Description: Multi-Interventional program for prevention and early Management of Anastomotic leakage after total mesorectal excision in Rectal cancer patIents, the IMARI-trial. This is a multicenter prospective clinical effectiveness trial. Primary objective: To increase the one year anastomotic integrity rate in patients undergoing total mesorectal excision (TME) for rectal cancer by the routine and quality controlled implementation of a multi-interventional program. Inclusion criteria: Patients with a diagnosis of primary rectal cancer with the lower border below the level of the sigmoid take-off on MRI, or regrowth in a watch and wait protocol, or undergoing completion/salvage surgery after local excision.  Data collection: CT scans, questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, serum, swab precacral cavity, swab anastomotic site, feaces. Experimental data: Genomics, microbiotica profilling, metatranscriptomics.

Name: CAMINO
Description: Clinical added value of MRI over CT in patients scheduled for local colorectal liver metastases (CRLM) therapy: a prospective, multicenter incremental diagnostic accuracy study. Primary objective: To evaluate the clinical impact (i.e. finding additional clinically significant (CS)-CRLM) of liver-MRI in addition to CT chest/abdomen in patients scheduled for curative therapy for primary or recurrent CRLM. Inclusion criteria: All patients with primary or recurrent CRLM who are considered candidates for curative surgery, (percutaneous or open) ablation only or combination of curative surgery and per-operative ablation based on CT chest/abdomen. Data collection: MRI scans, CT scans (Clinical data currently not available for third parties).

Name: PROCORE
Description:
PROCORE is a prospective population-based study with the focus on chemotherapy
induced peripheral neuropathy and the impact on colorectal cancer patients lives. Primary objective: To gain insight into the incidence and severity of chemotherapy induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) symptoms in colorectal cancer (CRC) patients. Inclusion criteria: CRC patients stage I-IV. Data collection: Questionnaires. Sample collection: Whole Blood, Plasma, DNA,  Buffy Coat. Experimental data: Genomics (Not available yet for third parties)

Name: CAIRO 3
Description: Maintenance treatment with capecitabine and bevacizumab versus observation after induction treatment with chemotherapy and bevacizumab as first-line treatment in patients with advanced colorectal carcinoma: a randomised phase III study. Primary objective: To determine the efficacy of maintenance treatment with low-dose capecitabine (XelodaR) plus bevacizumab (AvastinR) in patients with advanced colorectal cancer. To determine the safety aspects of this regimen. To assess the progression-free survival (PFS2) after induction treatment with XelodaR, EloxatinR (MTD chemotherapy), and AvastinR, followed by randomisation to observation (arm A) versus maintenance treatment with low-dose XelodaR plus AvastinR (arm B), followed upon progression (PFS1) by re-introduction of MTD chemotherapy and AvastinR in patients with advanced colorectal cancer. Inclusion criteria:  Patients with histological proof of colorectal cancer (in case of a single metastasis, histological or cytological proof of this lesion should be obtained, distant metastases (patients with only local recurrence are not eligible), unidimensionally measurable disease (³ 1 cm on spiral CT scan or³ 2 cm on chest X-ray; liver ultrasound is not allowed), in case of previous radiotherapy, at least one measurable lesion should be located outside the irradiated field and ongoing or planned first line treatment with 6 cycles of Xeloda, Eloxatin, and Avastin. Data collection: CT scans, questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, Tissue microarray (TMA), HE slides, circulating tumour cells (CTC), DNA, RNA, mRNA, plasma, serum, protein. Experimental data: Genomics, proteomics, transcriptomics, pharmacogenomics. Molecular analyses: Snp, TMA: expression of TRAIL, DR4, and DR5, chromosomal imbalances, microsatellite instability, p53 mutation, inflammatory cells proteins, expression of  Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF) and other pro- and antiangiogenic molecules, levels of  insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) and IGF binding proteins in serum, and expression of IGFs, their receptors and IGFBPs in tumour material, coagulation: D-dimer C16 TF+-MPs.

Name: CAIRO 5
Description: Treatment strategies in colorectal cancer patients with initially unresectable liver-only metastases CAIRO5: a randomized phase 3 study of the Dutch Colorectal Cancer Group (DCCG). Primary objective: To determine the median progression-free survival (PFS) upon induction systemic treatment in colorectal cancer patients with initially unresectable liver-only metastases, stratified by RAS and BRAF tumor mutation status and primary tumor location. Inclusion criteria: Unresectable metastases confined to the liver, RAS and BRAF mutation status known. Data collection: BRAF status, RAS status. Sample collection: Tissue, DNA, microRNA, plasma. Experimental data: Genomics , metabolomics , proteomics, transcriptomics. Molecular analyses: CNV, WGS, WES.

Name: CAIRO 6
Description: Perioperative systemic therapy and cytoreductive surgery with HIPEC versus upfront cytoreductive surgery with HIPEC alone for resectable colorectal peritoneal metastases: a multicentre, open-label, parallel-group, phase II-III, randomised superiority study. Primary objective: To compare the oncological efficacy of perioperative systemic therapy and cytoreductive surgery with Hypertherme Intraperitoneale Chemotherapie (HIPEC) (experimental arm) versus upfront cytoreductive surgery with HIPEC alone (control arm) for isolated resectable colorectal peritoneal metastases (PM). Inclusion criteria: No previous HIPEC, pathologically proven peritoneal metastasis (PCI <20), no systemic metastases, no systemic chemotherapy <6 months. Data collection: CT scans, questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, plasma, ctDNA. Experimental data: Genomics. Molecular analyses: WES, CNV.

Name: FIT
Description: Multicentre randomized controlled trial comparing ferric(III)carboxymaltose infusion with oral iron supplementation in the treatment of preoperative anemia in colorectal cancer patients. Primary objective: To investigate which route of iron supplementation is superior in the treatment of iron deficiency anemia in patients with colorectal carcinoma. Inclusion criteria: Patients with M0- stage colorectal carcinoma and concomitant iron deficiency anemia (Hb < 8 mmol/l (13 g/dl) for men and TSAT < 20 %) who will undergo a laparoscopic/open segmental colonic resection or (low) anterior resection. Data collection: Case record forms, questionnaires

Name: PUMP trial
Description: Adjuvant hepatic arterial infusion pump chemotherapy after resection of colorectal liver metastases in patients with a low clinical risk score: a phase III randomized controlled open label, multicenter trial. Primary objective: To compare the progression-free survival (PFS) of surgery with adjuvant hepatic arterial infusion pump (HAIP) chemotherapy to surgery alone in patients with resectable colorectal liver metastases with a low clinical risk score (CRS 0-2). Inclusion criteria:: Patients with resectable colorectal liver metastases (CLM) without extrahepatic disease (EHD). Data collection: CT scans, questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, Plasma, Serum, ctDNA. Experimental data: Genomics, Pharmacokinetics.

Name: 50FG
Description: 50 healthy volunteers that have been seen 4 times every 3 month within 1 year. In fact this study is a follow up on the 500FG cohort within the HFGP.

Name: Collison
Description: Colorectal liver metastases: surgery versus thermal ablation: a phase III single-blind prospective randomized controlled trial. Primary objective: To prove non-inferiority of thermal ablation compared to hepatic resection in patients with at least one resectable and ablatable colorectal liver metastases (CRLM) and no extrahepatic disease. Inclusion criteria: Resectable and ablatable CRLM, (≤3cm) (= target lesion),  maximum of 10 CRLM, additional resections for unablatable CRLM and/or ablations for unresectable CRLM are allowed. Data collection: Questionnaires

Name: Collision-XL trial
Description: Unresectable colorectal liver metastases: stereotactic body radiotherapy versus microwave ablation: a phase II prospective randomized controlled trial for colorectal liver metastases 3-5 cm. Primary objective: To compare efficacy of microwave ablation (MWA) to the efficacy of stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) with regards to the primary endpoint (local tumour progression free survival at 1 year in patients with unresectable colorectal liver metastases (CRLM) (3 – 5 cm). Inclusion criteria: Patients with 1-3 unresectable CRLM size 3-5 cm eligible for both MWA and SBRT (target lesions), additional CRLM are allowed if considered either resectable or ablatable and <3cm. Data collection: Questionnaires

Name: ENCORE
Description:
Energy for life in colorectal cancer survivors: How do physical activity and dietary factors affect their quality of life?
Primairy objective: To investigate the influence of physical activity and dietary factors on the quality of life of colorectal cancer survivors after treatment.
Study design: In a cohort of colorectal cancer survivors, changes in physical activity and dietary factors in relation to changes in quality of life after treatment will be studied prospectively. In addition, the proposed research questions will be studied cross-sectionally in individuals from two to ten years after treatment of colorectal cancer. Inclusion criteria: Established diagnosis of stage I, II or III CRC, including recurrent CRC (Prospective study), history of stage I, II or III CRC, including recurrent CRC, for which the cases concerned received treatment in the preceding 2 to 10 years (Cross-sectional study). Data collection: MRI scans, CT scans and questionnaires. Sample collection: From 80 patients per year  (prospective) + 216 patients (cross-sectional) is expected to collect; Tissue, plasma, serum and DNA. Experimental data: Genomics, proteomics, metabolics.

Name: MEDOCC-CrEATE
Description: Circulating tumor DNA based adjuvant chemotherapy in stage II colon cancer patients: the MEDOCC-CrEATE trial. A phase III randomized controlled trial according to Trials within Cohorts design.  Primary objective: To investigates how many patients with detectable ctDNA accept adjuvant chemotherapy (ACT) and whether ACT reduces recurrence rate. Inclusion criteria: Histological confirmed stage II colorectal cancer, fit enough to receive treatment with combination chemotherapy (fluoropyrimidine and oxaliplatin) according to the treating physician. Data collection: Questionnaires.  Sample collection: Tissue, plasma, ctDNA. Experimental data: Genomics

Name: 300 Diabetes Mellitus
Description: Diabetic patients (TD1) have been seen once for collection of biomaterial and questionnaire.

Name: MEDOCC
Description: A prospective observational trial to evaluate the prognostic value of ctDNA after resection of the primary tumor in stage II colorectal cancer patients. Primary objective: To determine the association between presence of ctDNA after surgery and recurrence and survival of disease in stage II colorectal cancer (CRC) patients. Secondairy objective: To determine if mutational status of detected ctDNA is associated with tumor characteristics and clinical outcome. Inclusion criteria: Histologically proven adenocarcinoma of the colon or proximal rectum without indication for neoadjuvant treatment. Suspected stage II or III CRC before surgery of the primary tumor. Data collection: Questionnaires.  Sample collection: Plasma, ctDNA, celpellet. Experimental data: Genomics

Name: Protect
Description: The PLCRC-PROTECT study: PLCRC cohort: Dietary intake after diagnosis and colorectal cancer outcomes. Primary objective: To investigate the association between diet and colorectal cancer (CRC) survival in patients diagnosed with stage I-IV CRC. Inclusion criteria: Histological proof of stage I-IV CRC, signed informed consent for participation in the PLCRC observational cohort study (and at least IC for filling in Quality of life questionnaires). Data collection: Questionnaires.

Name: Protect plus
Description: The PLCRC-PROTECT+ study: PLCRC cohort: lean bOdy mass and Treatment toxicitiEs in adjuvant ChemoTherapy-receiving colon cancer patients. Primary objective: To investigate the association between changes of lean body mass and overall grade 2-4 toxicity in patients with colon cancer who receive adjuvant chemotherapy. Inclusion criteria: Histological confirmed colon cancer, (high risk stage II or stage III), colon cancer patients who will receive adjuvant chemotherapy, signed informed consent for participation in the PLCRC observational cohort study and PROTECT study. Data collection: CT scans, questionnaires. Sample collection: Serum, plasma, cell pellets.

Name: OPTIC
Description: OPTIC (Organoids to Predict Treatment response In mCRC) is an multicenter observational cohort study. Primary objective: To validate the concept that ex vivo organoid response correlates to in vivo response to standard first-line, second-line or third-line treatment in mCRC patients on a metastasis level. Study design: This early phase biomarker development study is the first step in the evaluation of tumor organoids as a screening tool to predict treatment response to standard of care drugs in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC). Whole genome sequencing can additionally be performed to relate genetic characteristics to organoid drug screening results and patient response to treatment. lf the study results are promising we will use the data to expand the use of the technology for positive selection/prediction of treatment. Inclusion criteria: Patients with mCRC and a liver metastasis who will receive 1st, 2nd or 3rd line of chemotherapy and/or targeted agents. Data collection: Clinical response information (including CT scan RECIST values) and organoid drug response data (e.g. IC50) and WGS data. Sample collection: Tissue, organoids, serum, plasma, cell pellets, DNA, RNA. Experimental data: Genomics, Transcriptomics. Molecular analyses: RNA sequencing

Name: CONNECTION
Description: Improving clinical management of colon cancer through CONNECTION, a nationwide Colon Cancer Registry and Stratification effort (CONNECTION II Trial). A prospective, single arm, multicenter intervention study. Primairy objective: To evaluate the pathological tumor response to neoadjuvant systemic chemotherapy per consensus molecular subtype (CMS) in patients with microsatellite stable (MSS) high risk stage II and stage III colon cancer. Inclusion criteria: MSS based on pre-treatment biopsy by immunohistochemistry, adequate bone marrow, liver and renal function, fit to undergo neoadjuvant chemotherapy with CAPOX and subsequent surgery judged by the primary treating physician. Data collection: CT scans, MMR status, CMS data. Sample collection: Tissue, plasma.

Name: NTRK
Description: Prevalence of NTRK fusions in metastatic colorectal cancer patients. Primary objective: To estimate the prevalence of an Neurotrophic Tyrosine Receptor Kinase (NTRK) gene fusion in metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) patients with an microsatellite instable (MSI) tumor or a right sided colon cancer (CC) and determine the survival using the PLCRC infrastructure. Inclusion criteria: mCRC patients with a MSI tumor or right sided mCC, included in PLCRC with informed consensus for use of tissue. Data collection: Clinical data, NTRK fusion data. Sample collection: RNA (in a small subset of patients). Experimental data: Genomics, transcriptomics. Molecular analyses:  Targeted RNA-based next generation sequencing.

Name: RAPIDO
Description: The Rectal cancer And Pre-operative Induction therapy followed by Dedicated Operation (RAPIDO) study is a randomized multicentre phase III study. A short course radiation therapy followed by prolonged pre-operative chemotherapy and surgery in primary high risk rectal cancer compared to standard chemoradiotherapy and surgery and optional adjuvant chemotherapy. Primary objective: To decrease the disease related treatment failure (DrTF). Inclusion criteria: Biopsy-proven, newly diagnosed primary rectal adenocarcinoma + locally advanced tumour fulfilling at least one of the criteria on pelvic MRI indicating high risk of failing locally and/or systemically (see protocol). ECOG performance score < 1. Data collection: CT scans, MRI scans, questionnaires (Clinical data currently not available for third parties).

Name: ORCHESTRA
Description:
A randomized multicenter clinical trial for patients with multi-ORgan, Colorectal cancer metastases
comparing the combination of CHEmotherapy and maximal tumor debulking versuS chemoTheRapy Alone. Primary objective: To determine the overall survival benefit of >6 months. Inclusion criteria: Patients with multi-organ metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) with an indication for first line palliative chemotherapy with CRC metastases in ≥ 2 organs, Tumor debulking (at least 80%) is deemed feasible by an expert panel. Data collection:MMR status, quesstionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, DNA, microRNA, plasma, RNA, serum. Experimental data: Genomics, proteomics, transcriptomic.

Name: UNITED
Description: The UNITED study (Uniform Noting for International application of the Tumour-stroma ratio as Easy Diagnostic tool) is an international multicentre, prospective and retrospective study to validate the tumour-stroma ratio (TSR). Primary objective: To add, in addition to the TNM classification, the TSR to current routine pathology evaluation. Inclusion criteria: All patients that are diagnosed with pathological stage II or III colon cancer. Data collection: TSR score. Sample collection: Tissue stained (H&E slides)

Name: 200 Human Immunodeficiency Virus
Description: The 200HIV cohort is part of the Human Functional Genomics Project (HFGP). Between 14 December 2015 and 6 February 2017,  consecutive individuals living with HIV were recruited from the HIV clinic of Radboud university medical centre. The Human Functional Genomics Project (HFGP) aims to disentangle interindividual variation in human immune responses in healthy and patient populations, by combining clinical, genetic, and immunological data.

Name: Lateral Nodal Recurrence in Rectal Cancer (LaNoReC)
Acronym: Lateral Nodal Recurrence in Rectal Cancer (LaNoReC)
Description: The Lateral Nodal Recurrence in Rectal Cancer (LaNoReC) trial is a prospective registration study aimed at increasing national awareness for enlarged lateral nodes and their role in local recurrences. Primary objective: To investigate whether optimal standardised radiotherapy protocols and selective indicated lateral lymph node dissections (LLNDs) can reduce the lateral local recurrence rate to 6%, as described in relevant literature. Inclusion criteria: All patients with rectal cancer and one or more enlarged lateral node(s) (a short axis of 7mm or larger) in the internal iliac or obturator compartment measured on the initial MRI, will be included. Data collection: Lateral local recurrence data, MRI scans,  questionnaires.

Name: INTERACT
Description: Concomitant intraperitoneal and systemic chemotherapy in patients with extensive peritoneal carcinomatosis of colorectal origin: A fase I dose-escalation study. Primary objective: To establish the maximum tolerable dose (MTD) of intraperitoneal irinotecan added to systemic FOLFOX and bevacizumab. Inclusion criteria: Patients with peritoneal carcinomatosis, fit for therapy, life expectancy of at least 3 months. Data collection: CT scans, MTD data. Sample collection: Ascites, organoids, peritoneal fluid, whole blood. Experimental data: Genomics

Name: TESAR
Description:
Rectal preserving treatment for early rectal cancer. A multicentred randomised trial of radical surgery versus adjuvant chemoradiotherapy after local excision for early rectal cancer. In additon we added a wait and see registration arm. These patients recieve a strict follow-up schedule. The follow-up data is being collected without using any randomization or intervention. Primary objective: To determine the oncological safety, treatment related morbidity, and the functional outcome of rectal preserving therapy for early rectal cancer. 
Inclusion criteria: Indication for completion total mesorectal excision after local excision high risk T1 or low risk T2 after R0 resection, without signs of lymph node or distant metastasis. Data collection: CRF, clinical folllow-up data, questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, HE slides, RNA, protein. Experimental data: Proteomics, transcriptomics.

Name: COLOR III
Description:
A multicentre randomised clinical trial comparing transanal total mesorectal excision (TME) versus
laparoscopic total mesorectal excision for mid and low rectal cancer. Design: non inferiority. Primary objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of transanal total mesorectal excision (TaTME) for patients with mid and low rectal cancer. Inclusion criteria: Mid or low rectal cancer, distance 0-10cm from anal verge (MRI defined), Stage I-III (MRI and CT abdomen), curative intent (including downstaged after neoadjuvant therapy); Intention for primary anastomosis. Data collection: Video of surgery, quality assessment data, MRI scans, questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue.

Name: SERUM-DAB-LUMC
Description: Duchenne & Becker

Name: PLCRC
Description:
Prospective Dutch Colorectal Cancer cohort (PLCRC), is a population based observational cohort study for all
Dutch patients diagnosed with colorectal cancer. The cohort serves as an infrastructure for a wide variety of research projects including etiological, biomarker, basic, (epi)genetic, and interventional (according to the Trials within Cohorts (TwiCs) design), as well as health-care policy and cost-effectiveness studies. Primary objective: To establish a continuous source for a large variety
of research purposes. Inclusion criteria: Patients with stage I to IV colorectal cancer (CRC), patients newly diagnosed with CRC and/or currently being treated for CRC. Data collection: Extensive longitudinal clinical data, patient-reported outcomes (PROs),  Sample collection: Tissue, Plasma, Serum.

Name: Colopec
Description: Adjuvant hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy in patients with colon cancer at high risk of peritoneal carcinomatosis; the COLOPEC Dutch randomized multicentre trial. Primary objective: To determine the effectiveness of adjuvant hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy (HIPEC) in preventing the development of peritoneal carcinomatosis (PC) in high-risk patients. Inclusion criteria: Patients who underwent intentionally curative resection for a T4N0-2M0 or intra-abdominally perforated colon cancer,  patients with a adequate clinical condition to undergo simultaneous HIPEC or re- laparoscopy or re-laparotomy with HIPEC within either 10 days or between week 5-8 from primary resection. Data collection: CT scans, questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue.

Name: STAR-TREC II
Description: Can we Save the rectum by watchful waiting or TransAnal surgery following (chemo) Radiotherapy versus Total mesorectal excision for early REctal Cancer? The STAR-TREC phase II  study is an international, multi-centre, randomised trial, comprising a 1:1:1 randomisation for eligible subjects with a small, clinically localised rectal cancer between: (a) Conventional TME surgery, (b) Organ saving utilising long course concurrent chemoradiation, (c) Organ saving utilising short course preoperative radiotherapy. Primary objective: To assess the feasibility of a large, multi-centre randomized trial comparing radical surgery versus organ saving treatment using (chemo)radiotherapy followed by selective transanal microsurgery. Inclusion criteria: Patients with rectal cancer, staged by CT and MRI as T1-T3b (less than 40mm diameter) N0M0.  Data collection: Case report forms, questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, H&E slides

Name: STAR-TREC III
Description:
Can we Save the rectum by watchful waiting or TransAnal surgery following (chemo) Radiotherapy versus Total mesorectal excision for early REctal Cancer? The STAR-TREC phase III study is an international, multi-centre, partially randomised,
patient preference study comprising a 1:1 randomisation for subjects with a small,
clinically localised rectal cancer choosing an organ preservation approach between: (a) Organ saving utilising long course concurrent chemoradiation, (b) Organ saving utilising short course radiotherapy. The phase III study will also include a standard Total Mesorectal Excision (TME) radical surgery (non-randomised) comparator arm encompassing reconstructive (low anterior resection) and no reconstructive (abdominoperineal excision, low Hartmann’s procedure) approaches. Primary objective: To evaluate two contrasting organ preservation strategies (either long-course chemoradiotherapy or short course radiotherapy) for the treatment of early stage rectal cancer in terms of organ preservation rates, toxicity (clinician and patient reported) and Health-Related Quality of Life (HRQoL). Inclusion criteria: Patients with rectal cancer, staged by CT and MRI as ≤ cT3b (up to 5mm of extramural spread) N0M0. Data collection: Case report forms, questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, whole blood, ctDNA, H&E slides. Experimental data: Genomics.

Name: CAIRO
Description: Sequential versus combination chemotherapy with capecitabine, irinotecan, and oxaliplatin in advanced colorectal cancer (CAIRO): a phase III randomised controlled trial. Primary objective: To assess the efficacy, defined as overall survival, of sequential versus combination chemotherapy for advanced colorectal cancer (CRC). Inclusion criteria: Patients were eligible if they had histologically proven colorectal cancer that was in an advanced stage not amenable to curative surgery, together with measurable or assessable disease parameters (serum carcino embryonic antigen as the only parameter for disease activity was not allowed), and no previous systemic treatment for advanced disease. Previous adjuvant chemotherapy was allowed provided that the last administration was given at least 6 months before randomisation. Eligible patients had to have a WHO performance score 0–2 and adequate hepatic, bone marrow, and renal function.Data collection: CT scans, questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, DNA,RNA. Experimental data: Genomics, Transcriptomics. Molecular analyses: Tissue microarray, Comparative genomic hybridization (CGH) array, Expression array, microsatellite instability (ploidy assessment and MSI-analysis).

Name: PIPAC II
Description: Bidirectional treatment consisting of repetitive laparoscopic electrostatic pressurized intraperitoneal aerosol chemotherapy with oxaliplatin (ePIPAC-OX) and systemic intravenous chemotherapy for isolated unresectable colorectal peritoneal metastases: feasibility, safety, tolerability, and preliminary efficacy. Primary objective: To determine the safety of bidirectional therapy, consisting of repetitive laparoscopic ePIPAC-OX combined with systemic intravenous chemotherapy, for isolated irresectable colorectal peritoneal metastases (PM). Inclusion criteria: Histologically confirmed PM from a colorectal (including appendix) carcinoma that are not amenable for complete cytoreductive surgery. Data collection: CT scans, CMS data. Sample collection: Tissue, plasma, ctDNA, DNA, microRNA, organoids, ascites. Experimental data: Genomics, protemics

Name: PLCRC-ORCA
Description: Liquid biOpsies in Ras wildtype metastatic colorectal CAncer patients: an exploratory study. Primary objective: To explore changes in RAS mutation status in ctDNA of patients with RASwt mCRC treated with different palliative treatment regimens over time. Inclusion criteria: Patients with RASwt metastatic colorectal cancer ( who are treated with palliative intent).Data collection: Questionnaires, RAS mutation status. Sample collection: Tissue, DNA, ctDNA, Plasma. Experimental data: Genomics

Name: SURE
Description: Strict surveillance after endoscopic resection of high-risk T1 colonic cancer. Can we prevent unnecessary surgery? Primary objective: To evaluate the oncological outcome of endoscopically removed high-risk T1 carcinoma in patients who prefer surveillance with salvage surgery in the event of recurrence, with patients who prefer immediate completion surgery. Inclusion criteria: Prior local excision of a T1 colonic carcinoma with one or more tumor related risk-factors, but no procedure-related risk factors; negative oncological staging procedures including abdominal-thoracic CT scan and normal CEA; Karnofsky Performance index ≥ 70; fit for segmental oncological bowel resection; life-expectancy for ≥ 5 years. Data collection: CT scan, case report forms, questionnairs. Sample collection: Tissue

Name: PLCRC-QUALITAS
Description: Quality of life in metastatic colorectal cancer patients treated with trifluridine-tipiracil in late line in the PLCRC cohort. Primary objective: To evaluate quality of life from start to end of treatment with trifluridine-tipiracil in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer unresponsive to or intolerant for standard therapies and treated with trifluridine-tipiracil treatment. Inclusion criteria:  Patients with metastatic colorectal cancer which are included in PLCRC and starting treatment with trifluridine-tipiracil. Data collection: Questionnaires.

Name: Eurocat NNL
Description: Data on children with congenital anomalies and their parents, including risk factors
Biobank Label: UMCG Cohort and Biobank Coordination hub

Name: PUMP-III
Description: Adjuvant hepatic arterial infusion pump chemotherapy after repeat hepatectomy for patients with liver confined recurrence of colorectal cancer ;a multicenter single arm phase II study. Primary objective: To investigate whether additional  hepatic arterial infusion pump (HAIP) chemotherapy improves liver-specific disease-free survival in patients with recurrent liver metastases from colorectal cancer compared to resection alone. Inclusion criteria: Patients with histologically confirmed colorectal cancer and a ECOG performance status of  0 or 1. Patients which have recurrent colorectal colorectal liver metastases (CRLM) after previous liver metastasectomy, no (history of) extrahepatic metastases, no second malignancy < 5 years previously, no residual CRLM after first. Data collection: CT scans, questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, Serum. Experimental data: Genomics, Pharmacokinetics.

Name: PROVENC3
Description: PROgnostic Value of Early Notification by Ctdna in Colon Cancer stage 3 (PROVENC3) is a prospective observational subcohort of the Prospective Dutch Colorectal Cancer Cohort study. Primary objective: To determine the prognostic value of post-surgery ctDNA in stage III colon cancer patients treated with adjuvant chemotherapy (ACT) in order to reduce futile treatment. Inclusion criteria: Patients with stage III colon cancer treated with ajuvant chemotherapy. Data collection: Questionnaires. Sample collection: Tissue, TMA (from primary tumor), DNA/RNA (from primary tumor), cell-free Plasma, ctDNA (from cell-free plasma), cel pellet, germline DNA (from cell pellet). Experimental data: Genomics. Molecular analyses: Tumor tissue DNA/RNA sequencing data and plasma ctDNA sequencing data.

Name: PUMP-IT
Description: Hepatic arterial infusion pump chemotherapy combined with systemic chemotherapy (PUMP-IT); a multicenter phase II, interventional  feasibility study. Primary objective: To prove feasibility of the hepatic arterial infusion pump (HAIP) chemotherapy (floxuridine) in combination with systemic chemotherapy consisting of FOLFOX or FOLFIRI. Inclusion criteria: Adult patients with  potentially resectable colorectal liver metastases (CRLM) without extrahepatic metastases  and an indication for standard first or second line systemic therapy (FOLFOX or FOLFIRI).  Data collection: CT scans, case report forms and questionnaires.

Name: CAIRO 7
Description:
Radioembolization with 166Ho-microspheres in elderly and/or fragile patients with previously untreated unresectable liver-only metastases of colorectal cancer, CAIRO7 study endorsed by the Dutch Colorectal Cancer Group (DCCG); a randomized phase II clinical study. Primary objective: To demonstrate efficacy radioembolization in terms of progression free survival in colorectal cancer patients with liver-only metastases who are candidates for palliative systemic treatment with capecitabine plus anti-VEGF antibody (bevacizumab or biosimilar). Inclusion criteria: Elderly and/or fragile patients with liver-limited, unresectable
metastatic colorectal cancer, previously not systemically treated, who are candidates for systemic treatment with capecitabine plus an anti-VEGF antibody. Data collection:  Electronic case report forms, RAS status, BRAF status, V600E mutation status, MMR status of tumor, CT scans, questionnaires.  Experimental data: Genomics

Name: URINE-DAB-LUMC
Description: Duchenne & Becker

Name: AGE-CRC
Description: Advanced Geriatric Evaluation in predicting long term health related quality of life in elderly patients with ColoRectal Cancer; a multicentre, prospective, observational cohort study. Primary objective: A) To determine the predictive value of frailty characteristics for loss of health related quality of life (HRQL) in elderly patients with non-metastatic colorectal cancer (CRC). B) To develop an AGE-CRC score, a prediction model for loss of HRQL in elderly patients with CRC based on comorbidity, risk factors and frailty. Inclusion criteria: Patients aged ≥ 70 years with a new diagnosis of non-metastatic CRC. Data collection: AGE-CRC score, Predictive value of different frailty characteristics e.g. mobility, cognitive functioning, nutritional state, polypharmacy, sarcopenia etc, CT/MRI scans (muscle mass) and questionnaires.

Name: Mucosal immunity Covid-19
Description: Prospective cohort study of 50 index cases with laboratory-confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection and their household contacts. Development of mucosal immune responses is studied in relation to viral load, clinical symptoms and transmission characteristics.

Name: COPP study : a national registration study into COVID-19 in children
Description: The goals of the study are;Describing clinical manifestations of COVID-19 in children who are presented or admitted to hospital;Describing the course, treatment (including supportive treatment) of the disease;Determining risk factors for severe manifestation of the disease;Characterize the body’s reaction to infection with SARS-CoV-2;Describing inter-regional treatment variations in Dutch hospitals.This is a countrywide multicenter, observational prospective cohort study.

Name: Living and Working in Coronavirus Times Project and Survey
Description: WageIndicator Foundation is surveying / interviewing people in 140 countries to explore the COVID-19 effect on jobs, workload, working from home, job losses, and working conditions. Control variables relate to occupation, firm size, employment contract, household composition, life satisfaction, and Corona-cases in respondent’s networks at home and at the workplace. The surveys are in the national language(s). Given that a random sampled global survey is beyond budget and impossible in a brief time frame, the survey is a volunteer web-survey with snowball recruiting through many frequently visited websites with high quality search engine optimization and through social media. The results are shown in maps and graphs, updated on a daily basis. Researchers from CLARIN ERIC, SSHOC Project and the University of Amsterdam are cooperating in the project. In addition, WageIndicator collects for a few countries the COVID-19 response of companies, and has developed a data collection regarding country-level measures related to work and employment.The surveys are accessible here (select a country and a language in case of multilingual countries):https://wageindicator.org/salary/living-and-working-in-times-of-the-coronavirusThe codebook is available here:https://wageindicator.org/documents/publicationslist/publications-2020/corona-survey-codebook_20200330.pdfThe data of the survey is available for non-commercial use at IZA DATA ARCHIVE in Bonn, and is every weekday updated at noon:https://datasets.iza.org/dataset/1388/living-and-working-in-coronavirus-times-surveyThe maps are available here:https://iltuosalario.it/carriera/vivere-e-lavorare-ai-tempi-del-coronavirus/coronavirus-mappeThe country-level overview of measures is available here:https://paycheck.pk/career-tips/living-and-working-in-times-of-the-coronavirus/covid-19-labour-market-reforms

Name: COVID-19 in rheumatic patients: a prospective cohort study
Description: The influence of the presence of an inflammatory rheumatic disease and its treatment on the severity of and immune response to (viral) infections is not clear. The emergence and pandemic of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) provides the opportunity to assess these influences on COVID-19 incidence, its clinical severity, and the antibody response, compared to a control population. This is a prospective observational cohort study with a follow-up of 6 months. The study population will consist of participants with a systemic autoimmune disease. Each patient will be asked to provide a healthy control without a systemic autoimmune disease from his/her social group or household to ensure that there is a comparable chance of exposure to SARS-CoV-2 in the control group. All participants will be at least 18 years old. In total, we expect to include 8000 subjects. Our primary study parameter is the percentage of subjects with a positive IgM or IgG response admitted to the hospital. Other parameters include the geometric mean antibody titre over time in participants and the percentage of IgM/IgG positive participants admitted to the ICU, or death. Another study parameter will be the geometric mean and incidence of different antibody profiles (IgM/G/A, IgG1/3) and repertoire (anti-SP, anti-NP), and the geometric mean antibody avidity in participants. In addition, the percentage of patients that adjusted their DMARD treatment will be compared between IgM/IgG positive and negative patients. The effect of these adjustments on the mean rheumatic disease activity will also be investigated.

Name: LUMC-Hemiplegic migraine
Description: The LUMC has studied hemiplegic migraine since the nineties, and in 1996 we were involved in finding the gene responsible for familial hemiplegic migraine type 1, CACNA1A. During our years of studying the disorder we have accumulated a large data set of hemiplegic migraine patients, with and without mutations in the known hemiplegic migraine genes (CACNA1A, ATP1A2 and SCN1A). This biobank holds blood, liquor, cell lines, clinical information and imaging data.
Sample Access Description: For sample access please contact the contactperson to discuss the posibilities.
Data Access Description: For sample access please contact the contactperson to discuss the posibilities.

Name: Technical development in junior speed skaters
Description: Longitudinal and cross-sectional data of technique development during a 1500m for junior speed skaters. Observational data from healthy people.
Data Access Description: Data is available upon request via Dr. Marije Elferink-Gemser (m.t.elferink-gemser@umcg.nl).
Biobank Label: UMCG Cohort and Biobank Coordination hub

Name: Self-monitoring and personalized feedback as a tool to boost depression treatment
Description: Pragmatic randomized controlled trial to study the efficacy of two experience sampling intervention modules for depression.
Data Access Description: Researchers are advised to first contact the listed contact person for more information about ZELF-i, such as current research projects, available data, and how to get access to ZELF-i data. In short: to apply for ZELF-i data by external users, a research protocol and analysis plan need to be submitted, which will be reviewed by the PIs. Once the application has been approved, applicants will receive a Data Transfer Agreement (DTA). The DTA describes in detail which data is being acquired and the purposes and terms for using them. The release of data starts off when the DTA has been signed by both parties.
Biobank Label: UMCG Cohort and Biobank Coordination hub

Name: Evaluation of systemic awareness training for medical students
Data Access Description: For reuse of the data please contact the contact person of the study
Biobank Label: UMCG Cohort and Biobank Coordination hub

Name: NVvR COVID-19 Initiatief BeeldBank Radiologie (NCIF)
Description: National register of pseudonymized radiological images (CT/Xth) of patients with (suspicion on) a COVID-19 infection for quality purposes and research, open to participation by all Dutch hospitals.

Name: Learning by Moving
Description: The overall aim of the Learning by Moving study is to investigate the effects of two types of physical activity on cardiovascular fitness, gross motor skills, cognitive functions, academic achievement, brain structure, and brain fucntioning in 8-10-year-old typically developing children. Furthermore, relateions between the physical and cognitive domain will be investigated.
Biobank Label: UMCG Cohort and Biobank Coordination hub

Name: MeDAS PET: a non-invasive imaging tool for quantitative assessment of myelin loss in multiple sclerosis
Description: PET and MR imaging dataset of patients (n=10) with primary and secondary progressive multiple sclerosis.
Sample Access Description: To obtain access to the full data set, a research proposal and analysis plan has to be submitted, which will be revised by the research board of the Medical Imaging Center. For researchers outside of the UMCG, and once the application has been approved, applicants will receive a Data Transfer Agreement (DTA), which describes in detail the data that is being acquired and the purposes and terms for using them. A small fee might be required to access the data, which will cover the associated costs of data retrieval and transfer.

Name: Nijmegen Biomedische Studie
Description: The Radboud Biobank was established in 2012 with the goal of providing an infrastructure within the Radboud university medical centre for the collection, storage and management of biomaterial and the matching clinical data. The construction is based on the model developed for this purpose by the Parelsnoer Institute (PSI). It is expected that the scientific data created with the help of this infrastructure will lead to improved health in patients and reinforce the position of biomedical research in Nijmegen.

Name: NBCS (Nijmegen Blaaskankerstudie)
Description: The Dutch patients were recruited for the Nijmegen BladderCancer Study (NBCS: http://dceg.cancer.gov/icbc/membership.html). The NBCS identified patients through thepopulation-based regional cancer registry held by the ComprehensiveCancer Centre East, Nijmegen, that serves a region of1.3 million inhabitants in the eastern part of the Netherlands(www.ikcnet.nl). Patients diagnosed between 1995 and 2006under the age of 75 years were selected and their vital statusand current addresses updated through the hospital informationsystems of the seven community hospitals and one universityhospital (Radboud University Nijmegen MedicalCentre, RUNMC) that are covered by the cancer registry.All patients still alive on 1 August 2007 were invited to thestudy by the Comprehensive Cancer Center on behalf of thepatients’ treating physicians. A second group of patients, diagnosedbetween 2007 and 2008, was invited in 2009. In case of consent, patients were sent a lifestyle questionnaire to fill outand blood samples were collected by Thrombosis Servicecenters which hold offices in all the communities in theregion. In total, 1940 patients were invited to participate. Ofall the invitees, 1275 gave informed consent (66%): 1185filled out the questionnaire (61%) and 1219 (63%) provideda blood sample. The number of participating patients wasincreased with a non-overlapping series of 439 bladdercancer patients who were recruited previously for a study ongene–environment interactions in three hospitals (RUNMC,Canisius Wilhelmina Hospital, Nijmegen, and StreekziekenhuisMidden-Twente, Hengelo, the Netherlands). Ultimately,completed questionnaires and blood samples were availablefor 1429 and 1691 patients, respectively. All the patientsselected for the analyses (n ¼ 1631) were of self-reportedEuropean descent. The median age at diagnosis was 62(range 25–93) years. Eighty-two percent of the participantswere males. Data on tumor stage and grade were obtainedthrough the cancer registry.

Description: The Radboud Biobank was established in 2012 with the goal of providing an infrastructure within the Radboud university medical centre for the collection, storage and management of biomaterial and the matching clinical data. Name: AGORA
Description: The AGORA (Aetiologic research into Genetic and Occupational/Environ¬mental Risk Factors for Anomalies in Children) data- and biobank aims to facilitate research into the aetiology of major structural birth defects and childhood cancer by routinely collecting data from patients with these disorders and from a population-based control group. Data include DNA samples of children and parents as well as clinical data and parental questionnaires on a large range of non-genetic risk factors.

Name: Radboud Biobank Systemische Sclerose
Description: The main objective of the Biobank Systemic Sclerosis is the structured storage of human tissue and clinical information, both for our own research purposes and for (inter) national partnerships in the future. In particular, research into underlying pathophysiological mechanisms will be the main objective, with the consequent development of new diagnostic methods and possibly even the development of new mechanism-based therapies. De Biobank Systemische Sclerose heeft als belangrijkste doelstelling de gestructureerde opslag van lichaamsmateriaal en klinische informatie, zowel voor onze eigen onderzoeksdoeleinden als ook voor (inter)nationale samenwerkingsverbanden in de toekomst. Hierbij zal met name onderzoek naar onderliggende pathofysiologische mechanismen de belangrijkste doelstelling zijn, met daaruit voortvloeiende ontwikkeling van nieuwe diagnostische methoden en mogelijk zelfs de ontwikkeling van nieuwe mechanism-based therapieën.

Name: Intellectual Disability
Description: Every patient with intellectual disability (ID), where the diagnostic process has already been completed, is asked to participate. The extent of ID is determined on the basis of the IQ. For young children whose determination of an IQ score is not (yet) possible, a development index or the developmental age is used. If this is significantly behind the average (2 standard deviations or more) or if there is an IQ <70 then a patient or his / her parents / guardian is asked to participate in the Biobank ID. However, if there is a congenital / acquired developmental delay, a patient will not be included.

For some patients, patient-reported outcome measures will be available.  More info: www.probci.nl or contact Dr. A. Richters (a.richters@iknl.nl).

Name: Radboud Expertisecentrum Geslacht & Gender
Description: Scientific research can optimize the treatment of people with different forms of DSD or with gender incongruity / dysphoria. This can improve the options and better tailored care to the patient. However, scientific research is needed to gain insight into the underlying mechanisms. Knowledge about DSD and gender incongruity / dysphoria can potentially be used to better treat patients in the future. One of the ways in which scientific research is carried out uses the patient's body material.Certain body materials and personal data of patients undergoing treatment within the Sex & Gender Expertise Center are used and centrally stored in a specially developed archive that is specifically intended for this body material and personal data. This makes it possible to answer different scientific research questions now and in the future from different angles and by different researchers conducting scientific research on DSD and gender incongruity / dysphoria.

Name: Nederlandse Lyme expertisecentrum
Description: Het doel van de biobank en bijbehorende patiëntregistratie van het Nederlands Lyme expertisecentrum (hierna NLe Biobank) is de verzameling en de langdurige opslag van biomaterialen (zoals bijvoorbeeld plasma, afweercellen en DNA) met de bijbehorende klinische en epidemiologische gegevens voor toekomstig onderzoek naar diagnostiek en behandeling van lymeziekte.De afdelingen infectieziekten van het Radboudumc en het Amsterdam UMC, locatie AMC zijn de klinische centra binnen het Nederlands Lyme expertise centrum. Samen met het RIVM en de Lymevereniging vormen zij het Nederlands Lyme expertisecentrum. Voor de oprichting van de NLe Biobank is een subsidie toegekend door het ministerie van VWS.

Description: Hyperintense is a  prospective observational cohort study, designed to investigate the effects of acute changes in blood pressure on brain (micro)structure and vascular function, measured with MRI, in young-middle aged adults with hypertension.

Name: Coronis
Description: Onderzoek naar prevalentie en risicofactoren van herseninfarcten na COVID-19

Name: Genetics and Rare Disease
Description: Patients with a (rare) disease where the cause is expected or has already been proven to be genetic. Eligible patients  had genetic counseling and/or genetics testing at the department of Human Genetics, Radboudumc.

Name: ADOPT
Description: Androgen Deprivation therapy for Oligo-recurrent Prostate cancer in addition to radioTherapy (ADOPT)The overall aim of this project is to test the hypothesis that the addition of Androgen Deprivation therapy (ADT) to metastasis-directed radiotherapy (MDRT) in well-selected prostate cancer (PCa) patients with oligo-metastatic disease prolongs the metastasesprogression-free survival (MPFS) compared to MDRT alone.An important clinical question is how to identify those patients with oligo-recurrent PCa that might benefit from an aggressive local treatment. Patients that do not benefit from this approach could be spared the burden of such a treatment and might benefit more from an upfront aggressive approach with systemic agents.In the present biobank, we will capture cfDNA from plasma to determine the cfDNA concentration, copy number variations and mutations in relevant genes. This data will be used to find biomarkers predictive for response.

Name: Myotone Distrofie
Description: Myotonic dystrophies type 1 and type 2 are progressive multisystem genetic disorders with clinical and genetic features in common. Myotonic dystrophy type 1 is the most prevalent muscular dystrophy in adults and has a wide phenotypic spectrum. Myotonic dystrophy type 2 tends to cause a milder phenotype with later onset of symptoms and is less common than myotonic dystrophy type 1.

Name: Erfelijke Lysine Metabolisme Defecten
Description: Erfelijke metabole aandoeningen vormen een grote groep van meer dan 1400 zeldzame aandoeningen, waarbij door een foutje in het DNA afwijkingen optreden in het proces waarbij eiwitten, vetten en koolhydraten worden omgezet in kleinere bouwstoffen en energie. Aangedane individuen hebben levenslange fysieke en cognitieve beperkingen, vaak zijn de aandoeningen progressief. Radboud wil op termijn expertise centrum worden

Name: Radboud Biobank Oncologie

Name: SPIDI

Name: PRECISE
Description: The PRECISE project aims to collect biological material from patients with metastasized bladder cancer or melanoma who are treated with immunotherapy. This material will be used to identify novel predictive biomarkers and to develop diagnostic tests based on those markers.Participants will be recruited from 5 different centers.

Name: Mycobacterial Cohort Study
Description: De primaire doelstelling van de ‘MyCoS biobank’ is het opzetten van een prospectieve cohortstudie met gegevens verkregen tijdens de reguliere zorg, aangevuld met onderzoeksdata, van patiënten met TB en NTM infecties.

Name: Biobank Hereditary Colorectal Cancer
Description: Affected and unaffected patients at increased risk of hereditary colorectal cancer and/or polyposis, or with a proven germline mutation causing colorectal cancer and/or polyposis are included. Both clinical data (demographic data, details on medical and family histo¬ry, information on surveillance, endoscopy and surgery, results of microsatellite instability and molecular genetic tests) and biomaterial (DNA, plasma, serum and tissue) are collected in a standardized manner.

Name: Diabetes
Description: Het Parelsnoerinitiatief heeft als doel om binnen de academische centra een infrastructuur te realiseren voor het verzamelen van klinische data en opzetten van biobanken op interuniversitair niveau. Het UMC St Radboud neemt als universitair medisch centrum deel aan het Parelsnoerinitiatief. Het ziektebeeld diabetes is binnen het UMC St Radboud één van de parels waarvoor het implementatie traject gestart wordt. Implementatie houdt in het proces van inclusie van een patiënt in het parelsnoercohort, vastleggen van klinische gegevens, afname en opslag van biomateriaal en publicatie van deze gegevens aan het centrale Parelsnoer Initiatief.

Name: Ischemische hartziekten
Description: Containing patients with ST elevation myocardial infarction with a blood sample prior to primary PCI- and patients with chronic heart failure based on ischemic heart disease with a blood sample during outpatient visit. Follow-up is obtained yearly

Name: PancreasParel
Description: Het doel van de PancreasParel is het opslaan van pancreasweefsel en bloed bij elke electieve pancreasoperatie (ongeacht indicatie)ten behoeve van wetenschappelijk onderzoek naar pancreas‐ en periampullaire tumoren en chronische pancreatitis.

Name: Parel Hemofilie
Description: Cross-sectional sampeling of Male Dutch patients with a clinical diagnosis of severe, moderate, or mild haemophilia A or B. Blood samples and urine samples are stored in the Biobank.

Name: Clinical features of SARS-CoV-2
Description: There is a great need for detailed clinical data to help improve diagnostic and therapeutic management and identify predictors for poor outcome. Our study aims to describe clinical, laboratory and radiological characteristics and to identify prognostic biomarkers for poor outcome of COVID-19 cases that are hospitalized in five hospitals in the south of The Netherlands. This will help to gain scientific knowledge of the emerging disease and improve clinical algorithms and prognostic factors for outcome of COVID-19. At this moment, we have a large database including detailed clinical information and plasma/serum samples of multiple timepoints for more than 1100 PCR-confirmed COVID-19 patients from 6 hospitals in The Netherlands. This combined database provides the opportunity to identify prognostic factors for poor outcome of COVID-19 based on clinical characteristics as well as biological factors. The primary aims of this database are 1) to describe the clinical course of COVID-19 in hospitalised patients and to identify clinical risk factors for severe disease, 2) to identify and validate new prognostic biomarkers for poor outcome of COVID-19, and 3) to study a biological basis for the diversity in clinical presentation of COVID-19. In addition, this database provides the opportunity to study subgroups or subquestions related to COVID-19.

Name: Stichting Biobank Oost Nederland
Description: The aim of the Stibion biobank foundation is to enable and support research on and development of methods for health monitoring and early detection of disease. The Stibion biobank is building a collection of longitudinal biofluid sample series from people that started donating when healthy and became sick during the course of donating. Periodical urine and blood samples will be collected in combination with data on health history and current overall health generated by donor questionnaires and diagnoses of serious illnesses by associated general practitioners.

Description:
A cohort study about early detection of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) in unaffected mutation carriers. 
This cohort consist of 20 healthy controls with no mutation (relatives,  goal 30), 32 unaffected mutation carriers (goal 50), 24 idiopathic PAH patients with no mutation (goal 30), 29 hereditary PAH patient (goal 30)

Name: Fetal Aneuploidy Biobank
Description: This biobank contains samples from fetuses aged 12wk-24wk that have been made available after termination of a pregnancy for social reasons,because of the presence of a chromosome imbalance,because of the presence of major malformation(s),because of the presence of a gene variant. 3D MRIs (7T MRI) are made of all fetuses. Subsequently samples are taken from (almost) all organs that are useful for DNA, RNA and protein studies. Brains are stored in the national Dutch Brain Biobank.

Name: Pathologisch Anatomisch Landelijk Geautomatiseerd Archief
Description:
PALGA delivers data from national databases for purposes such as scientific research, medical quality control, and for the evaluation and monitoring of screening programmes. PALGA offers the option of linking data via a Trusted Third Party (TTP).

PALGA manages its own national database of pathology results. These excerpts date back to 1971. Coverage has been nationwide since 1991. This means that all 52 pathology laboratories are now connected to the national infrastructure. The wealth of information in the database offers researchers opportunities for study, all the more so because it is a gateway to the tissue archives. In addition, data from the database can be used for the quality control of screening programmes. It also serves as a signalling source for the Dutch Cancer Registry.
Sample Access Description: A 'request' (requests to retrieve data from PALGA's database) can be submitted via the PALGA Request System. You will first have to create an account before you can make use of this facility. You must complete a request procedure before you can retrieve data from PALGA's database. It is also possible to link a study cohort to PALGA's database, subject to strict privacy conditions.

You will first have to create an account before you can make use of this facility. You must complete a request procedure before you can retrieve data from PALGA's database. It is also possible to link a study cohort to PALGA's database, subject to strict privacy conditions.

Name: European cooperation in geriatric rehabilitation research after COVID-19
Description: Aims of the EU-COGER study: 1. To gain insight into recovery of older Covid-19 patients during and after stay at a rehabilitation department. 2. To gain insight into the content of post-Covid-19 rehabilitation in various European countries: What treatment strategies are used? Which professionals are involved?
Data Access Description:
Researchers who wish to conduct additional analyses can apply for 
EU-COGER research data by sending an application to P.I. prof. Wilco 
Achterberg (W.P.Achterberg@lumc.nl).  

A standardized application form is available and includes items such as 
the research question and a short analysis plan. The analysis plan 
should outline which statistical analyses will be conducted, which 
variables are needed, and – if applicable – which subset of the sample 
the researcher would like to use.

Applications will be judged based on the originality of the research 
question and the feasibility of the analysis plan. 

When the application is approved, a data transfer agreement (DTA) will 
be signed to ensure that the receiving party will adhere to our 
co-authorship policy and will not share the data with third parties (and
 will store the data in line with the General Data Protection Regulation
 (GDPR), in case of non-EU member states).
